conclusion: Determine the time during which there is an induced current in the frame as it moves through the magnetic field.
Identify the intervals during which the frame is in the magnetic field and calculate the time for each interval.

The frame has a side length \( l \) and the width of the magnetic field is \( d \). Since \( l < d \), the frame will be completely in the magnetic field for a certain period of time and will have parts outside the field for the rest of the time.
The frame enters the magnetic field when the left edge of the frame reaches the boundary of the magnetic field. This takes a time \( t_{\text{enter}} = \frac{l}{v} \).
The frame exits the magnetic field when the right edge of the frame leaves the boundary of the magnetic field. This takes a time \( t_{\text{exit}} = \frac{l}{v} \).
The total time for the frame to move a distance \( d \) is \( t_{\text{total}} = \frac{d}{v} \).
The time during which the frame is not in the magnetic field is \( t_{\text{not in field}} = t_{\text{total}} - t_{\text{in field}} \).
The time during which the frame is in the magnetic field is the total time minus the time it takes to enter and exit the field.

Since the frame is in the field for a time \( t_{\text{in field}} = \frac{2l}{v} \) (because it enters and exits the field), the time during which the frame is in the field is \( t_{\text{in field}} = \frac{d}{v} - 2 \cdot \frac{l}{v} + \frac{2l}{v} = \frac{d - 2l + 2l}{v} = \frac{d}{v} \).
The time during which there is an induced current in the frame is the time the frame is in the magnetic field, which is \( t_{\text{in field}} = \frac{d - l}{v} \).
